  Rejuvenation is recalling about 3,325 Deep Frame Mirrors due to an injury hazard. If you purchased one of these mirrors between July 2019 and March 2021, beware: According to a [recall alert](https://cpsc.gov/Recalls/2021/Rejuvenation-Recalls-Deep-Frame-Mirrors-Due-to-Laceration-and-Injury-Hazards-Recall-Alert) published by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, the glue on the back of the mirrors can fail and the glass can fall out of the frame, posing a laceration risk.

**This May Also Interest You:** [**Signature Hardware Stainless Steel Towel Grab Bars Recalled for Fall Risk**](https://www.homeserve.com/en-us/blog/home-improvement/towel-grab-bar-safety-recall/)

According to the July 1 recall, there have been 18 reports of the mirror detaching from the frame and the glass breaking. No injuries have been reported.

This recall involves [Rejuvenation](https://www.rejuvenation.com/landing/product-safety-recalls)’s Deep Frame Mirrors in round, square and arched shapes with bronze, brass or white finishes. They were manufactured in India and imported by Williams-Sonoma. The mirrors were sold in Rejuvenation stores, [Rejuvenation.com](http://rejuvenation.com/) and via the Rejuvenation catalog for $450 to $900.

To find out if your mirror is involved in this recall, find the stock-keeping unit (SKU) number and date code on the back of the mirror and check it against [this list](https://www.rejuvenation.com/landing/product-safety-recalls).

If you have one of these mirrors, you’ll want to stop using it immediately. Rejuvenation is contacting all known purchasers directly to coordinate a free replacement or a full refund. You can also reach the Portland, Ore.-based company at 877-770-7231, via email at [customerservice@rejuvenation.com](mailto:customerservice@rejuvenation.com) or online at [Rejuvenation.com](http://rejuvenation.com/). For more consumer product safety information, go to [cpsc.gov](https://www.cpsc.gov/).
